STATE OF MICHIGAN

GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 7, 2024
Holly Halabicky
Mission Ranch
9300 Lahring Road,
Gaines, MI, 48436
Re: License #: CI250410439
Dear Holly Halabicky:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
5/2/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-
6992.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
• (e) Three dated references which are
obtained prior to employment from
persons unrelated to the employee and
which are less than 12 months old.
Two of seven new employee files reviewed lacked documentation of three dated
references.
2

Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal, CAP approved 6/10/2024
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s
performance annually thereafter.
One of three new employee files reviewed requiring an evaluation lacked having
an evaluation completed.
Repeat Violation Established
2023 Renewal, CAP approved 6/10/2024
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete,
sign, and date an initial treatment plan for each
resident within 30 calendar days of admission.
Two of two youth files reviewed had late initial treatment plans by one day.
RFCAN 2.10 Services to be Provided d. Standardiszed On-going
Assessment Tools Page 12
1. The Contractor must utilize the following assessment
tools unless otherwise specified in Attachment A to
assess the youth’s needs and strengths while in the
residential program:
a) Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths (CANS),
3

Child and Adolescent Needs and Strengths (CANS), or
Child and Adolescent Functional Assessment Scale
(CAFAS), and
b) Casey Life Skills Assessment (CLSA) or Daniel
Memorial Assessment (for youth 14 years of age and
older).
2. The Contractor may utilize additional standardized
and reliable assessment tools to assess overall
progress in functioning.
Additional program specific assessment tools are
identified within each residential foster care program
type in Attachment A. The Contractor must administer
the assessment tool(s) at the interval indicated by each
tool until planned discharge.
Two of two youth files reviewed lacked Casey Life Skills or Daniel Memorial
Assessment for youth 14 years of age and older.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• CCI Rule 400.4113-1-b: The rule required a true copy of verification of education
from an accredited college or university where minimum education requirements
are specified by the rule, a professional license does not meet the rule
requirement.
• RFCAN 2.10 Services to be provided u) Behavioral Health Services 20 Psychiatric
Services: Within 15 calendar days of the youth’s admission to the facility, if
necessary, from the youth’s treatment plan, the psychiatrist must assess the youth
and coordinate with the licensed clinical personnel completing the psychosocial
assessment. The psychiatrist must review the youth’s medication history, current
needs, and prescriptions. This includes adjustment of medication and dosages, as
necessary. The facility will need to review the most recent completed treatment
plan at the youth’s admission to determine if the treatment plan indicates the
youth needs psychiatric services to be completed within the first 15 calendar days.
• CCI Rule 400.4155-3-d: The initial treatment plan shall include indicators of goal
achievement.
• CCI Rule 400.4155-3-e: The initial treatment plan shall include the person
responsible for coordinating and implementing the youth and family treatment
goals.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
4

• Consultation provided on completing three separate reference forms for employee
references verses all three references on one form.
• Consultation provided on when copying an employee’s diploma, for the staff
verifying the true copy, to sign and date the back of the photocopied diploma.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• 2023 Renewal Inspection: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this
reporting period as a result of the Renewal Inspection completed
5/19/2023. The violations where noted for employee personnel files,
employee training, treatment plans, initial documentation, personal
possession documentation and discharge summaries. The CAP contained
action items to ensure documents required for employee files were
obtained prior to hire by updating the hiring process to include a checklist
for employment to be utilized and confirm all required documents are
obtained prior to hire date. The facility updated the evaluation tool and
facilities policy to include thirty-day, six month, and annual evaluations. The
facility updated discharge form to include all required components per the
rule. The facility developed an inventory checklist to be used at admission
and discharge to account for youth belongings and created a discharge
policy and process. The facilities CAP was effective as marked by the
significant improvements of rule violations found during this interim
inspection.
• SIR2023C0000453SI, CAP approved 7/10/2023 was a result of violation
400.4109 (1) (c) for the facilities supervision policy. The facility retrained
staff on the care, safety, and supervision of youth as well as to how to
address supervision when youth are at the hospital.
• SIR2023C0000778SI, CAP approved 1/8/2024 was a result of violation
400.4109 (1) (c) for the facility failing to follow the agency supervision policy
during the midnight schedule as one staff entered a youth's bedroom alone
at night and 400.4142 (1) (a) due to failing to seek appropriate medical
attention for youth expressing suicidal ideations. The facility updated the
bed/night check policy and retrained staff on the updated policy. The facility
implemented a process for documenting two staff entering a youth's
5

bedroom at night and management implemented random checks to confirm
the process has been implemented and working. The facility developed a
protocol and checklist for when youth are experiencing suicidal ideation and
management reviews the checklist to ensure the protocol has been
followed.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facilities
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
the findings in the facilities first audit and CAP implemented assisted the facility in
addressing areas for improvement including additional staff training and
implementation of new processes. Chief Administrator identified additional staff
training and new process have had a positive impact on the facility.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported feeling supported by management at the facility and they enjoy
working at the facility. Staff feel the youth are well taken care of. Staff feel safe
and prepared with training for the work they do. Staff did not have any concerns or
needs at this time.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. Youth report all their
needs are met at the facility. Youth report feeling supported and respected by staff
and management. Youth feel safe and reported no concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on May 2, 2024. The
facility was clean and had no safety concerns. All youth’s bedrooms were viewed
and had appropriate bedding. Medication and cleaning supplies were secured as
required. The fire extinguishers expire in June 2024.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
6

Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
5/7/2024
